content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The image displays multiple fragments of tissue, predominantly composed of adipose (fat) tissue, which is typical for a lymph node dissection specimen. I can identify several discrete, more basophilic (purple) nodules embedded within the fat, which are highly suspicious for lymph nodes. In total, there appear to be at least 4-5 potential lymph nodes or tissue nodules scattered across the slide. Some areas also show significant hemorrhage (red areas). My first impression is to systematically locate and examine each of these potential lymph nodes for evidence of cancer.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

The area highlighted by the green box is a well-circumscribed, densely basophilic (purple) nodule located within a larger piece of adipose tissue. This appearance is characteristic of a lymph node at low magnification. The primary task in a colorectal cancer resection is to assess the lymph node status (N stage). Therefore, it is standard procedure to zoom into every structure that resembles a lymph node to examine it at high power for the presence of metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, instead of normal lymphoid tissue, I see that the lymph node architecture is almost completely replaced by malignant glands. These glands are irregular, crowded, and show complex cribriform (sieve-like) patterns. The cells lining these glands exhibit significant nuclear atypia, including enlargement, hyperchromasia (dark staining), and irregular nuclear contours. There is also a desmoplastic stromal reaction (dense, fibrous connective tissue) surrounding the glands. This is a classic presentation of metastatic adenocarcinoma, consistent with a colorectal primary. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, completely effaced by metastatic tumor.
